Comment: Bakasa = to hunt. At 14:14 he gives a speech in Tetun Terik to warn hunting participants to listen to each other, not swear, so that we will get what we want.
See answer to 7 for an example.
Everyone understands the language used in ceremonies and traditional stories. Eik nanoik = traditional stories.
Men and women can dance a lego-lego in a mixed fashion, with man-woman-man-woman etc.
In the rumah adat, men and women must meet separately.

This answer is given around question 10.3, where he explains about the ritual and the language used.The ritual takes place every year before the harvest and involves cutting up a  goat or a pig and the meat is lifted up, and a prayer is said to the sacred objects in the rumah adat and the ancestors (around 01:07; another one at 01:30, with free translation in Indonesian.)
the rumah adat but also the land where crops are planted
Rice wine, sirih pinang
The rumah adat.

After the baby is born, the umbilical cord and placenta are put on the top of a tree. There is a ritual called fasi matang 'wash eyes', takes place a week after a baby is born. It does not involve washing anything, but rather cutting off some of the baby's hair. The parents and family express various types of good wishes to the child.
A body is buried after 3 days, covered in traditional woven cloth. After the burial, food and drink is put at the grave for 40 days.
Before planting, the land is cermoniously sprinkled with coconut milk to make it fertile.
Tetun Terik woven cloth from Viqueque are special, they have their own colours and patterns.
baba = small drum held at shoulder (Tetun D liku rai); korneta = flute, tambor = drum
The question is understood to be about brushing teeth.
In the past, it was normal to not cut a boy's hair until he is grown up. The cutting took place when he was an adult, and was part of a ritual. The hair was put below a banana tree.
In the past, men had ear piercings. Today, this is also a modern style.
Head piece for women made from male chicken feathers and plaited leaves: man fulung. Men do not have any leg adornments in Viqueque.
Fita lima = bracelet for men made of copper (?), kai bouk = head piece for men, morteng = necklace for women.Gold or silver is not used.
See 13.4 and 13.5

Loro mosu = East (sun go.up); loro tung (sun go.down) = West; tasi feto (sea female)= Northern sea, tasi mane (sea male) = Southern sea. Because the waves in the northern sea are less wild than  those of the southern sea of Timor. Fulang loro = moon sun;  ina fulang, ama loro = mother moon, father sun; kuana = right, karuk = left.
Tetun Terik speakers also speak Makasae and Naueti, Makasae speakers also speak Tetun Terik and Naueti in Viqueque.
When children are still small, they speak only Tetun Terik. But when they grow up to become adults they also learn Makasae and Naueti.

When the spouse comes from somewhere outside Viqueque, they speak Tetun Dili.But it is better if the spouse learns to speak Tetun Terik, because many people in Viqueque do not speak Tetun Dili very well.When the spouse is from Viqueque they both speak Tetun Terik.
When the wife comes from outside, she would learn Tetun Terik or else she would have difficulties communicating with her family and neighbours in Viqueque.
If necessary they use a third language but over time, the wife who does not speak Tetun Terik will learn her husband's language.
yes,10% or less   Bakasa = to hunt. Wild pigs, deer.
The sea is too far from Viqueque.
yes, 70-80% of the people have cattle    goats, pigs, chicken, water buffalo, horses, dogs, cows ('sapi Bali'); everyone has chicken and pig but not everyone has goats, cows and buffalos
Mostly dry gardens, there are also wet rice fields which are irrigated. The gardens are ~10 km from the house, the rice fields are closer.
Gardens are left for a year because otherwise the soil is not fertile enough
coconuts, rice, corn, green beans, candle nut, sugar cane, cassava, potato
The  notion 'suku' or 'clan' is unclear. The question is interpreted as: are there 'rumah adat'. This seems to be a moiety rather than a clan.

In Viqueque there are the following 'rumah adat' (some examples): Betuk Hun (betuk=k.o.big.bamboo, hun=tree), Kai Boki, Jan Bua Mahan, Balidi Mahan, Manu Uen (mahan=shade, balidi = buah asing, manu=chicken, uen = liquid, melt). The speaker belongs to Betuk Hun. This group comprises about 40 people. These 5 rumah adat are mutually connected. In the past, they could intermarry, but nowadays this is forbidden by the church because the family connections are too close.
Each of the five groups mentioned above has its own rumah adat.
Yes, the Betuk Hun, Kai Boki and Jan Bua Mahan have kings, but the Balidi Mahan and Manu Uen do not.
There are dialectal differences but they are geographically determined, not following clan lines.

A king did not own all the land. In the Portuguese times, kings did have the privilige that only their children could go to school. Groups with kings are Betuk Hun, Kai Boki and Jan Bua Mahan, the other two groups are not kings. Later, as a response to question 8.5, a royal family named Uhacae is mentioned (in Viqueque, desa Umain Kraik), and it is said that they own all the land.
Only sons inherit.
Only sons inherit.
The eldest son is the heir, if he has one or more brothers, these may get some of the heirloom, depending on what the parents decide, but most of it (at least 75%) goes to the eldest son.
A newcomer can buy land. When he dies, his heirs keep the ownership because they have a written contract. For example, Chinese. But there are very few foreigners that buy land. Javanese rent land.

In former times, men should marry at about 30, women at about 20     Nowadays there are no age restrictions, girls can get married at 15, boys at 17-19. The explanation for the earlier age restrictions is that boys and girls should first become adults before they get married. Later marriage is not related to organizing a bride price.

yes, in earlier days there were rules but not anymore            In former times, cousins could get married, but this is no longer allowed by the church. The first step in a marriage is when the two parties meet to negotiate. This is called: kasu lia 'let go/loose voice' = to inform.
Food and drinks are exchanged as a public sign that the couple is married. Food may be rice, drinks may be water or palm wine.
Before they get married, the bride price must be there. If there is not enough yet then he will not ask for the woman.
They belong to the husband's kin group but can stay somewhere else for work, e.g. live in Dili.
Formerly, this was not obligatory, but nowadays it is.
The children remain with the father, even if he remarries.
It still happens, e.g. when a wife cannot have children, or had children who died, then the man can get a second wife. The two women live in the same house with the man.

Makasae and Fataluku women are expensive, Tetun Terik women are less expensive. The bried price consists of money, buffalo, horses, woven cloth, necklace, earrings. The term for bride price is fo feto foling lit. 'give woman price'.
Only pigs, to be eaten by the family at the wedding. No clothes or other objects are given by the bride's side.

Some families may temporarily live away from the village, to e.g. guard the gardens, or work in the gardens. But these are temporary settlements. (It is mentioned that the Naueti place where the president of Timor Leste comes from, does have such dispersed family homesteads, because each family must stay on its own land.)
Villages usually have more than 2000 inhabitants.
This is found in e.g. the Betu Hun group.
For Tetun people that live in the mountains.
For Tetun people that live near the coast.

This is the place for ritual ceremonies, feto sau mane 'make adat'. The ritual building is an uma dato 'rumah adat', this is where ceremonial meetings are held and rituals are performed, and the sacred objects of the group are kept. (See also answer to 10.3). At 11:55 there is a story about the history of Tetun people. In the past, seven brothers from the kings clan Betun came from Atambua, one settled in Suai, one in Same, two in Atambua, two in Viqueque, one in Manatuto Suai Bada. This is why Tetun Terik is spoken in these places.
The traditional rumah adat building may be referred to with data wahing, makai fukun (data = sacred, wahing = much; makai fukun is a parallel expression without meaning.)
Raised approx. 1 meter

The house is long, with two long slopes on the long sides, and two short slopes on the short sides. There is a door in the front, where the men enter, and a door at the right side, where the women enter. The men sit in the front end of the house. The kitchen is inside of the house, at the back end. This is the place for the women.
patrilineal
Every moiety has its own leader. The leader is chosen by consensus among the adult men of the family. Age is important.
See answer to 6.6 and 6.7.
The wife of a ketua adat can represent him, e.g. when he died or is elsewhere. Otherwise, women cannot have leadership roles.
Men and women can enter the rumah adat, but in the house, the men sit in the front and the women in the back.
yes, hereditary   In Viqueque (desa Umain Kraik) there is a royal family, called Uhacae. They have been kings since the past till now.
yes, hereditary   There are slaves living in Selur. They have to serve the royal family. They are not allowed to do other work or live somewhere else.
ema seluk, bai naka = foreigner. Lit. 'person else'
Name is taken from the father's family.
The name of an ancestor/parent can only be given when the person has died, not when he is still alive.
Tetun Terik is not a locaility name.
ema seluk, bai naka = foreigner. Lit. 'person else'
